derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (in the sense 'injury, hurt'): from Old French, hurt', from the verb nuire, from Latin nocere 'to harm'

entry.def: If you say that someone or something is a nuisance, you mean that they annoy you or cause you a lot of problems.

example.ex: He could be a bit of a nuisance when he was drunk...

means.word_mean: 1. (law) a broad legal concept including anything that disturbs the reasonable use of your property or endangers life and health or is offensive

Sentence.sentence: It will be more than a nuisance if we don't meet on delivery date.
In America, white tailed deer are more numerous than ever before, so abundant in fact that they've become a suburban nuisance and a health hazard.
